content: You’re onto something… I agree that the basis for anti-media attitudes is an “empowered” public questioning authority and doubting incentives, and that’s very different from our popular conception of a sedate audience passively being manipulated by propaganda. Conservative media subverted critique by positioning *themselves* as the unbiased media critics (we report, you decide). So the message can’t simply be, “don’t trust the official story”…. because for all the talk of personal responsibility, at some point, trust in *someone* is necessary. The most clever manipulators earn that trust through flattery and tribal signals… “you can’t trust anyone, but hey, we trust you.” As for the futility of fact-checking, I’m afraid it’s going to get much worse. In my industry (3D/VR), we’re very close to the point where someone can quickly create a realistic 3D model of your face, simply using publicly-available images from Google, and quickly create a realistic model of your voice, simply using publicly-available clips on YouTube. They can then animate this virtual avatar to say anything. And it will look very real. The path forward is hazy indeed, but I suspect we need to be thinking less about truth and verification, and more about trust and tribalism.
